Endagorion's blog

Pinely Round 5 editorial
By Endagorion, history, 6 weeks ago,

We hope you've enjoyed the problems! (Certain problem editorials below may appear a bit late due to Polygon lag)

2161A - Round Trip

Since div.1 rounds are always rated for all participants, we need to maximize the number of div.2 rounds. This means we should always try to decrease our rating until it reaches X−1 so we can participate in div.2 rounds too. After that, every round will be rated.

2161B - Make Connected

There are two types of connected areas that satisfy the condition that "No three consecutive black cells should be aligned vertically or horizontally".

2×2 square: 

##
##

Zigzags (there are four kinds of them):

##...
.##..
..##.
...##
....#

#....
##...
.##..
..##.
...##

...##
..##.
.##..
##...
#....

....#
...##
..##.
.##..
##...

For the square, you can simply check that there is a square and no other black cells.

For the zigzags, you can handle just one kind and handle others by flipping and rotating the grid.

To check that a zigzag fits the current grid, you can find the top-left and bottom-right black cells (for the first and second kinds), then verify that other black cells are only along the zigzag path between these two cells.

An alternative solution relies on the diagonal characterization. The zigzag characterization above can be succinctly explained as "in one of the two diagonal orientations, the black cells are constrained to two neighbouring diagonals". Since x+y and x−y values enumerate the diagonals with respect to their order, we find that the answer is "YES" if at least one of the following conditions holds:

  • among black cells (x,y), max,
  • among black cells (x, y), \max (x - y) - \min(x - y) \leq 1,
  • black cells are constrained to a 2 \times 2 square, that is \max x - \min x \leq 1, and \max y.- \min y \leq 1.

2161C - Loyalty

The best possible answer that we can achieve is obtaining bonus points for purchasing \lfloor {\sum_1^n a_i \over X} \rfloor of the most expensive items. And this number of bonus points always can be reached.

Let's sort the items in non-decreasing order by price and purchase the most expensive one if its purchasing increases loyalty level and adds bonus points; otherwise, just purchase the cheapest one.

It is easy to see that when 1 \leq a_i \leq X, we indeed always get bonuses for the prefix of the most expensive items with such strategy because purchasing one item can't increase our loyalty level by more than one.

2161D - Locked Out

Let b denote the sequence of pairs (a_i, i), sorted by the first component in non-decreasing order and, in the case of equal first components, in non-increasing order by the second component. Denote the first element of the pair b_i as b_{i,1} and the second element as b_{i,2}.

For example, for the array 3, 1, 2, 5, 2, this sequence will be (1, 2), (2, 5), (2, 3), (3, 1), (5, 4).

We will use this sequence to compute the following dynamic programming state dp_i: the maximum number of elements that can be in a good array if we have considered the elements of the array corresponding to the prefix of sequence b of length i.

The transition is defined as: dp_i = max\left(1, \max_{1 \leq j < i, (b_{i,1} \neq b_{j,1} + 1 \lor b_{i,2} < b_{j,2})}(dp_j + 1)\right)

To eliminate the quadratic complexity of this transition, we can maintain:

  • A global maximum among such j that b_{j,1} \leq b_{i,1} - 2;
  • Suffix maxima for such j that b_{j,1} = b_{i,1} - 1;
  • The maximum among such j that b_{j,1} = b_{i,1}.

The answer is n - \max_{1 \leq i \leq n}(dp_i)

2161E - Left is Always Right

Let [l, r] be the substring s_l \ldots s_r, and d[l, r] be (number of 1s) minus (number of 0s) among s_l, \ldots, s_r.

Consider d[1, k]. Note that it can't be 0 since k is odd. In the sequel we assume d[1, k] > 0 (the other case is fully symmetrical, and the answers for both options should just be added together).

We must then have s_1 = 1. If d[1, k] > 1 and k < n, then d[2, k + 1] \geq 1, therefore s_2 is also 1. Otherwise we have d[2, k] = 0, and s_2 = s_{k + 1} since s_{k + 1} determines the majority in [2, k + 1].

Continuing these comparisons to the right, we have one of two options:

  • There is a first position l \leq n - k + 1 such that d[l, l + k - 1] = 1. Then s_1 = \ldots = s_l = 1, and since d[l + 1, l + k - 1] = 0, the rest of s is fully determined by copying characters in [l + 1, l + k - 1] with period k. Note that in this case, if l > 1, then we can't have s_{l + k - 1} = 1, since otherwise l - 1 would be an earlier valid candidate.
  • For all l \leq n - k + 1 we have d[l, l + k - 1] > 1. Then s_1 = \ldots = s_{n - k + 1} = 1, and the suffix [n - k + 2, n] is arbitrary such that d[n - k + 2, n] > 0.

We can enumerate valid strings satisfying these options separately. In the first case, for a fixed first position l \leq n - k + 1 we have to ensure all of the following:

  • s_1 = \ldots = s_l = 1,
  • d[l + 1, l + k - 1] = 0,
  • s_j = s_{j - k} for all j > l + k,
  • if l > 1, then s_{l + k - 1} = 0.

Processing values of l from right to left, we can keep track of how much of the periodic suffix is fixed, namely, for each j = l + 1, \ldots, l + k - 1, which non-? characters appear in the pattern in positions j, j + k, \ldots. Assuming no contradictions arise, the number of valid suffixed can then be found as a binomial coefficient.

The case when all d[l, l + k - 1] > 1 is somewhat easier, since we only need to count the number of ways to fill [n - k + 2, n] such that the balance is positive; this is again a sum of binomials.

2161F - SubMST

Consider a subset S of vertices, and its partition into connected components of the subgraph G_S if only those edges of G with weight at most x are considered. If C(x) if the number of such components of G_S, the weight of MST can be found as \sum_x x \cdot (C(x - 1) - C(x)) = \sum_x C(x). Intuition: if C(x - 1) - C(x) = k, then exactly k edges of weight x are going to be needed.

Let us provide a different way to describe the partition in terms of T that doesn't construct the graph explicitly.

Suppose that edges of T are subdivided: an edge of weight w becomes a chain of 2w edges, each new edge has weight 1/2. For each v \in S, put all vertices in the subdivided tree that are at distance at most x/2 from v in the same component as v. Intuition: if any v, u \in S are at distance at most x in T, they will share a component with the midpoint of the path vu. On the other hand, separate component can never become connected because any pair of vertices is too far apart.

How do we find values of x when C(x) changes? Consider a subdivided tree vertex z; we will say that z is a point of contact at time x, if there at least two subtrees of T with respect to z such that the shortest distance between z and any v \in S in the respective subtree is x. Intuition: that's exactly when a midpoint is reached by both ends. We are then going to find the answer by summing over all possible points of contact.

Let's now say that S is a random set, with probabilty of v \in S equal to 1/2. Which points of contact occur and with which probability?

  • If z if an original vertex of T, we can find the probability distribution of the shortest distance to a v \in S within each subtree with respect to z. The matching distances d between subtrees can be located, and x = 2d summed with corresponding probabilities easily enough.
  • If z belong to the proper interior of an edge ab, we can still find probability distributions of closest v \in S in the two halves of T with respect to the edge ab. Suppose that the shortest distances end up being d_1 and d_2 respectively, and also that the length of ab is L. A point of contact occurs somewhere on the edge ab if and only if |d_1 - d_2| < L, with x = d_1 + d_2 + L. Summing this with respective probabilities can be done effiiciently with two pointers on the sorted probability distributions of d_1, d_2.

The most demanding part of this is computing sorted distributions, which is done easiest if, for each vertex v \in T, we have a separate list of all vertices u \in T sorted by \mathrm{dist}(u, v). That is possible to do in O(n^2) complexity in total.

Note: we've omitted the case where more than two directions come in contact simultaneously, but it is not that hard to handle (e.g. via considering subtrees of a proper vertex z one by one, and applying the usual treatment to "shortest distance in the new subtree" and "shortest distance among all the old subtrees").

2161G - Bitwise And Equals

Let up_X(z) be the lowest y \ge z such that y \& X = X. It's clear that a'_k \ge up_X(a_k) for all k. In fact in optimal solution at most one a'_k \neq up_X(a_k). Indeed, if for some k that inequality holds, then a'_k differs from up_X(a_k) by changing one bit b_k from 0 to 1 and setting smaller bits equal to corresponding bits in X. Then over all k with condition a'_k \neq up_X(a_k) it's enough to change only one with highest b_k.

So for one test we need to calculate all up_X(a_k), find the highest bit in (up_X(a_1) \,\&\, up_X(a_2) \,\&\, \ldots \,\&\, up_X(a_n)) - X (let's call it b) and change one bit from 0 to 1 in up_X(a_k) which is bigger than b (with corresponding change of lower bits). Here we need to be careful with the case when all but one values a_k contains some bit: We are not allowed to change this one.

We need to understand how to make this procedure fast enough. Let's start with calculating \sum (up_X(a_k) - a_k). How to calculate up_X(z) in a naive way? We need to find highest bit in X that is not contained in z, change this bit and set all smaller bits as in X. Let x_1, \ldots, x_t are bits of X starting from highest. So to calculate \sum (up_X(a_k) - a_k) we need to

  • find all indices i that doesn't contains x_1 and add 2^{x_1} + (X \& (2^{x_1} - 1)) - (a_i \& (2^{x_1} - 1)) to the sum;
  • find all indices i that contains x_1 and doesn't contain x_2 and add 2^{x_2} + (X \& (2^{x_2} - 1)) - (a_i \& (2^{x_2} - 1)) to the sum;

    ...

  • find all indices i that contains x_t and doesn't contain x_1\, \ldots x_{t - 1} and add 2^{x_t} + (X \& (2^{x_t} - 1)) - (a_i \& (2^{x_t} - 1)) to the sum.

Basically we need to calculate sum of expressions over all values that contains some set of zeros. We can precalculate these sums with or-convolution.

The rest is easy: We need to go over all bits b from highest to x_1 + 1 and

  • if all numbers contains 1 in b-th bit, stop the procedure
  • if all but one contains 1 in b-th bit, skip the bit
  • if more than one contains 0 in b-th bit, choose a_j that doesn't contain this bit and has highest a_j \& (2^b - 1) and set 1 for b-th bit (as before, lower bits should become equal to corresponding bits in X) and relax the result.

2161H - Cycle Sort

First, suppose that the arrays consist only of 0s and 1s.

Suppose we want to learn the final value of b_i. If b_i = 1 initially, it's never going to change. If b_i = 0, then at times t = i, i + m, i + 2m, \ldots we look at the current value of a_{t \bmod n}; the first time we find a_{t \bmod n} = 1 we put b_i = 0 and a_{t \bmod n} = 1. If no such t < k is found, then b_i remains 1 throughout.

The same process can be modelled as follows: place "tokens" with numbers into positions 0, \ldots n-1 of the first array as follows:

  • If a_i = 0, put a token with value -\infty in its position.
  • If b_j = 0, put a token with value j in position j \bmod n.

Meaning of a token x at position i is as follows: during operation x a zero from the second array is going to be compared against a_i (unless x = -\infty, in which case a_i = 0 from the start).

With the tokens in place, we start applying the following operations:

  • If any token has x \geq k, it is discarded, and we conclude that b_{x \bmod m} = 1.
  • Otherwise, let i be any position which has more than one token. Then all tokens except for the smallest get moved to the position (i + m) \bmod n, and m is added to each of their values.
  • If none of the above is applicable, terminate. Put final a_i = 0 if position i contains a token, and 1 otherwise.

Observe that the order in which we apply the operations doesn't affect the final result.

To bridge with the original problem with numbers in 1, \ldots, n + m, consider a threshold x, then replace all numbers less than x with 0s, and all numbers at least x with 1s. In the final configuration the 0s and 1s will still correspond to "small" and "large" values in some order.

Consider changing x = 0, \ldots, n + m in this order. Each time we increase x, we may find the new final configuration and compare it with that of x - 1. We argue that the only position among a_i and b_i that contains 1 for x, but 0 for x-1, is exactly the final placement of the number x. To solve the problem in reasonable time complexity we now need to handle the 0-1 token process efficiently, as well as support "change a single 1 to a 0" queries.

Note that if \mathrm{GCD}(n, m) > 1, we may reduce to \mathrm{GCD}(n, m) independent problems. Assume that n and m are coprime from now on. If that's the case, after placing the initial tokens, we can renumber a_0, \ldots, a_{n - 1} in such a way that the tokens from i are moved to (i + 1) \bmod n instead of (i + m) \bmod n.

Suppose that for a threshold x both of the following conditions hold:

  • no tokens are ever expelled due to having x \geq k throughout the process,
  • the initial configuration of tokens has c_i tokens in position i.

If we were only to determine which positions i contain tokens in the end, we could resort to a "bracket sequence balance"-like argument: for all i \geq 0, we put

  • \Delta_i = c_{i \bmod n} - 1 to be the balance of the position i if the first array was repeated periodically (in practice two copies are enough).
  • S_i = \sum_{j = 0}^i \Delta_j — the prefix sums.

We argue that a position i doesn't contain a token in the end if and only if S_{i + kn} is the unique minimum on the prefix 0, \ldots, i + kn for all k \geq 0. Intuition: we can think of each position to potentially "consume" a single token (hence the -1 in the definition of \Delta). If S_j - S_i \geq 0, then the space between i+1 and j can't house enough tokens so that they become depleted as they are carried from i+1 to j, therefore they must spill over to j.

While this is enough to process a single threshold x efficiently, we also need to process the "change 1 \to 0" queries, which essentially adds a token somewhere in the initial configuration. We do it as follows:

  • Modify the segment tree such that for a position i we store the value of the largest token visiting i at any point. To accomodate for segment tree operations, these values, as well as balance sums and minimums, are enough.
  • When we've added a token, check if a token with value x \geq k appears anywhere. If that is the case, we can argue that this token can never become settled as a minimum, and therefore can be removed from the initial configuration altogether. When this happens, we can also deduce that a particular b_i has become 1 in the final configuration.
  • Otherwise, some a_i has become 1. Its position can be found from considerations. Tl;dr: if the token was added at position i, locate which minimum positive segment of balances contains i, then find its new rightmost point.
Tutorial of Pinely Round 5 (Div. 1 + Div. 2)

      Sure, so imagine, instead of finding the longest good subsequence, you try constructing a good sequence from the ground up. Let's say you put down a 77. Then you put down a few more 77's and you get an array like [7,7,7,7,7][7,7,7,7,7] or so.

      Now let's say you want to put down a 66. You cannot put any 66 before any 77, cuz that would violate the condition. So the only place to put the 66 would be after the 77's. Now you put some amount of 66's down, and you array must look like [7,7,7,7,7,6,6,6,6][7,7,7,7,7,6,6,6,6] or something. And if you try to put down some amount of 55's, the same thing happens to you: the 55's must be appended to the array.

      Now say you have the array [7,7,7,7,7,6,6,6,6,5,5][7,7,7,7,7,6,6,6,6,5,5], and you want to put down a 33 or even some value less than 33. It doesn't actually matter where you put the 33 (or the element lower than 33), cuz the 33 does not interact with the 55's (or anything above 55). So basically, you can splice together your array with, say, [3,3,3,2,2,1][3,3,3,2,2,1] in any way you want, and it won't cause an error.

      This means that any good array will basically consist of many subsequences, each one being of the form [x,x,…,x,x−1,x−1,…,x−1,x−2,x−2,…,x−r,x−r][x,x,…,x,x−1,x−1,…,x−1,x−2,x−2,…,x−r,x−r].

      Also, if the highest value in one of these subsequences is xx and the lowest is x−rx−r, then any value in the range [x−r,x][x−r,x] must be found in that nonincreasing subsequence. Furthermore, we cannot have the values x+1x+1 or x−r−1x−r−1 (the values just beyond the bounds of the subsequence) in the array, because, if these values are not included in the subsequence, they will also cause the condition to fail (if we can include these values in the subsequence, we do).

      Now we can define two dpdp arrays to solve this problem. Let dp1[val]=dp1[val]= the maximum length of a good array we can have if we only consider the elements with values ≤val≤val. The answer is just n−dp1[max(a)]n−dp1[max(a)].

      Now let dp2[val][i]dp2[val][i] be the max length of a good array given that we have considered all values <val<val and we have considered all values =val=val such that they are the ≥ith≥ith occurrence of valval in the array, and we include the ithith occurrence of valval in our good array. So like in the array [1,2,1,3][1,2,1,3], dp2[1][2]dp2[1][2] would only consider the second 11, and dp2[1][1]dp2[1][1] would consider both the first and second 11's (and it must include the first 11).

      To calculate dp2[val][i]dp2[val][i], you can consider 33 cases, but perhaps these can be simplified to just 22 cases.

      Let's consider the case where our subsequence including valval only includes values in the range [val,val][val,val] (and no other distinct values). Then we can say that dp2[val][i]=cnt[val]−i+1+dp1[val−2]dp2[val][i]=cnt[val]−i+1+dp1[val−2], where cnt[val]cnt[val] is the number of occurrences of valval in nums.

      Now there's the case where our subsequence includes val−1val−1 directly after the ithith occurrence of valval. In this case, dp2[val][i]=max(dp2[val−1][j])+1dp2[val][i]=max(dp2[val−1][j])+1, for all jj such that the jthjth occurrence of val−1val−1 comes after the ithith occurrence of valval. Basically, we try to prepend valval to the best subsequence starting with val−1val−1 that comes after our current occurrence of valval.

      There's one final case: our dp2[val][i]dp2[val][i] contains the (i+1)th(i+1)th occurrence of valval but it contains at least one val−1val−1. To cover this case, we can just say that dp2[val][i]=dp2[val][i+1]+1dp2[val][i]=dp2[val][i+1]+1 — we just prepend valval to the best subsequence including the (i+1)th(i+1)th occurrence of valval.

      dp2[val][i]dp2[val][i] is just the max over all three cases, and dp1[val]=max(dp1[val−1],dp2[val][i])dp1[val]=max(dp1[val−1],dp2[val][i]) for all 1≤i≤cnt[val]1≤i≤cnt[val]. You could probably simplify these transitions a bit, but I hope that this helped.

    +29

    Here's my implementation of problem B:

    Spoiler
    int main() {
  multiCase() {
    int n; cin >> n;
    auto M = read<string>(n);
 
    set<int> s1, s2, m1, m2;
 
    for (int i = 0; i < n; i ++)
      for (int j = 0; j < n; j ++)
        if (M[i][j] == '#')
          m1.insert(i - j), m2.insert(i + j), s1.insert(i), s2.insert(j);
 
    auto chk = [&] (set<int> st) {
      return st.size() <= 1 || *st.rbegin() == *st.begin() + 1;
    };
 
    bool flg = chk(m1) || chk(m2) || (chk(s1) && chk(s2));
 
    YES(flg);
  }
  return 0;
}

+5

For D simple hint Only consecutive value pairs (i, i+1) can violate the constraint. Store positions of each value, then for each pair, check if value i appears before i+1. When found, greedily remove the rightmost occurrence of i+1 to maintain maximum flexibility. This greedy approach works in O(n) time

+190

for D there is a very simple greedy solution 346684700. consider the graph where numbers are connected if they form a violating pair. we need to delete a minimum vertex cover in this graph. as the graph is bipartite, the minimum vertex cover size is equal to the maximum matching size by König's theorem. after that, it is pretty easy to see that maximum matching in this graph can be found greedily. consider the smallest value xx in the array. if there are multiple, consider the rightmost one. say, it's position is ii. this vertex is only connected to vertices with value x+1x+1 that have indices j>ij>i. it is now easy to see that if we consider the maximum matching, we can adjust it slightly to ensure that ii is connected to the maximum jj with value x+1x+1. therefore, we just repeat this greedy procedure of taking the right-most value ii and matching it to the rightmost value i+1i+1 if possible.

      +14

      ok. sure. this is a classical optimality argument for optimization problems. say, the smallest value is xx, and the rightmost position where xx occurs is ii. we match it to value x+1x+1 (as xx is the smallest value, no value x−1x−1 exists) at the largest position jj. if j<ij<i, there is nothing we can do with aiai so we just skip it. otherwise we match ii to jj. if there exists an optimal solution in which ii is matched to jj, then taking this pair is valid (we still can achieve optimal objective). otherwise, for contradiction assume that no optimal solution contains the pair (i,j)(i,j). consider an arbitrary optimal solution. what are ii and jj matched to in this solution? if either ii is not mached to anything, we can rematch jj to ii, and we will still have an optimal solution. this time it contains the pair (i,j)(i,j) thus leading to a contradiction with our assumption that no optimal solution contains this pair. anslogously, if jj is not matched to anything. otherwise, say ii is matched to kk and jj is matched to ℓℓ. i claim that rematching (i,j)(i,j) and (k,ℓ)(k,ℓ) always works. i will leave this for you to verify. this requires considering the two cases of what aℓaℓ is equal to.

        +1

        I came to a similar conclusion but broke it down in two parts. I'll post it here in case others find it useful to have a more detailed proof.

        It follows the strategy of first solving a restricted version of the problem, and then generalizing it, which is a very useful strategy to learn especially for lower ranked coders, since it works for many medium difficulty problems.

        Part 1

        Consider the simpler subproblem where the array aa has only two different values (w.l.o.g. 1≤ai≤21≤ai≤2). There is a simple greedy solution to find a maximum matching in this graph:

        Spoiler

        Let ii be the highest index where ai=1ai=1, then either i=ni=n so we can erase aiai because it cannot match anything, or i<ni<n which implies aj=2aj=2 for all i<j≤ni<j≤n and we choose some j, add (i, j) to the matching, and erase aiai and ajaj. Repeat until the array contains no more 1s.

        Proof

        The proof that this greedy approach works is by contradiction: consider a maximum matching that does not contain (i, j). Then j must be matched with some vertex h (h<jh<j, ah=1ah=1), since if j were unmatched we could add (i, j) for free, contradicting the assumption the the matching was maximum. But we can also replace (h, j) with (i, j) without changing the cardinality of the matching, showing that there is some maximum matching including (i, j).

        This explains the inner loop, though note that the argument above shows that it's not actually necessary to pick the last 2 every time. Any 2 following the last 1 would work, but picking the last 2 (i.e. choosing j=nj=n every time) is easiest to implement efficiently.

        Part 2

        Now consider the general case where 1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n. The crucial insight is this: if we consider the subgraph restricted to edges between values 1 and 2, then for any maximum matching in the subgraph, there is a maximum matching in the full graph that contains it as a subset!

        Proof

        Suppose edge (i, j) is in the maximum matching of the subgraph but not in the maximum matching of the full graph. That means ai=1ai=1 and aj=2aj=2, and j must be matched with some vertex k in the full graph (otherwise, we could just add (i, j) for free, again contradicting the assumption that the matching was maximum), and we can replace (j, k) with (i, j) without changing the cardinality of the matching.

        This directly leads to the greedy algorithm (your outer loop): find a maximum matching involving only edges between 1 and 2 (using the solution from part 1), then discard all 1s (which cannot be matched anymore) and all the matched 2s. Then the lowest remaining value is 2 and we can do the same with with edges between 2 and 3, and so on, n−1n−1 times in total.

        → Reply

+375

there is basically no editorial for the first three problems. this is a big issue in general on codeforces. ease problems seem obvious to the contest authors, and it is hard for them to emphasize with lower-rated participants. by saying "it is easy to see" you are robbing the beginner contestants from learing how to prove their solutions. people see this phrase being used all the time and just assume that problemsolving is about guessing the solution rather than proving it. the worst example is problem B. it is not easy to see that these are all possible shapes! it requires a proof. and reading such a proof would be extremely beneficial for some.

    +5

    If you understand the logic of the DP and don't know how to optimize, then you can see this code to understand the optimizations needed to find out dp[i].
    Following optimizations -
    // * A global maximum among such j that b_j,1 ≤ b_i,1 − 2
    // * Suffix maxima for such j that b_j,1 = b_i,1 − 1
    // * The maximum among such j that b_j,1 = b_i,1

    Code
    /* Coded by harshcooljn */

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
#include <iostream>
#include <stdint.h>
#include <ios>
#include <iomanip>
#include <numeric>
#include <math.h>
#include <vector>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <queue>
#include <utility>
#include <map>
#include <set>
#include <unordered_set>
#include <unordered_map>
#include <algorithm>
#include <string>
using namespace std;
typedef long long int ll;
typedef long double ld;
typedef unsigned long long int ull;
typedef pair<ll, ll> pll;
#define vll vector<ll>
#define vstr vector<string>
#define vvll vector<vector<ll> >
#define vpll vector<pair<ll,ll> >
#define endl '\n'
#define vin(v,a,n) for(ll i=a;i<n;i++){cin>>v[i];}
#define vinp(v,n) for(ll i=0;i<n;i++){ll x;cin>>x;v.push_back(x);}
#define pvec(v) for(auto &e: v){cout << e << " ";}cout<<endl;
#define pvecp(v) for (ll i=0;i<v.size();i++){cout << v[i].first << "," << v[i].second << " \n"[i==v.size()-1];}
#define parr(a,n) for(ll i=0;i<n;i++){cout << a[i] << "";}
#define parr1(a,n) for(ll i=1;i<=n;i++){cout << a[i] << "";}
#define yes cout<<"YES"<<endl;
#define full(v) v.begin(),v.end()
#define fr(i,a,n) for(ll i=a;i<n;i++)
#define fr_(i,n,a) for (ll i=n;i>=a;i--)
#define no cout<<"NO"<<endl;
#define spc ' '
#define nline cout<<endl;
#define fileIO freopen("/Users/harsh/Desktop/c++/codeforcesContest/input.txt","r",stdin);freopen("/Users/harsh/Desktop/c++/codeforcesContest/output.txt","w",stdout)
#define fastIO ios_base::sync_with_stdio(0);cin.tie(0);cout.tie(0)


void Solve(ll t10) {
    ll n;
    cin >> n;
    vll a(n);
    vpll b;
    fr(i, 0, n) {
        cin >> a[i];
        b.emplace_back(a[i], i);
    }
    sort(full(b), [&](pll& x, pll& y) {
        if (x.first == y.first) {
            return x.second > y.second;
        }
        return x.first < y.first;
        });

    // this sorting order is very important for correctness
    // we will iterate through array b
    // since it is sorted , the values will be increasing in a[i] and decreasing in i
    // lets define dp[i] = maximum number of elements we can include in a good array considering all elements from the prefix b[:i]
    // transition 
    // dp[i] = max(1, max(dp[j]+1)) such that , j < i && (b[j].second > b[i].second || b[i].first!=b[j].first+1)
    // this transition is correct , because lets say we have elements that we selected as follows in any dp[j]
    // _ _ _ _
    // now when looking at b[i].first , we know that it is >= any previously considered elements
    // if b[i].first == b[j].first + 1, then we will only take it if b[j].second > b[i].second
    // and we know that if it is less than b[j].second , then it will be less than indices of all b[j].first considered in dp[j] , since this one (at b[j].second) has the smallest index (among all b[j].first elements) , as we sort decreasing indices
    // else if b[i].first != b[j].first + 1 , then it can always be added
    // but this transition will result in a quadratic complexity


    // now we need to optimize the transition
    // so we need to maintain maximums 
    vll dp(n);
    ll ans = 1;
    vll max_by_element(n + 1); //max_by_element[i] = max ans seen by considering all elements <= i 
    vll max_by_equal_element(n + 1);
    map<ll, set<pll> > mp; // for b[i].first - 1
    ll cur = b[0].first;
    fr(i, 0, n) {
        dp[i] = 1;
        if (b[i].first != cur) {
            while (cur <= b[i].first) {
                max_by_element[cur] = max(max_by_element[cur], max_by_element[cur - 1]);
                cur++;
            }
            cur--;
        }
        if (b[i].first - 2 >= 1) { // extend from b[i].first-2
            dp[i] = max(dp[i], max_by_element[b[i].first - 2] + 1);
        }
        dp[i] = max(dp[i], 1 + max_by_equal_element[b[i].first]); // extend from b[i].first
        auto it = mp[b[i].first - 1].upper_bound({ b[i].second,0 });
        if (it != mp[b[i].first - 1].end()) {
            dp[i] = max(dp[i], (it->second) + 1); // extend from b[i].first - 1;
        }
        // Following would have been the equivalent brute force
        // fr(j, 0, i) {
        //     if (b[j].second > b[i].second || b[j].first + 1 != b[i].first) {
        //         dp[i] = max(dp[i], 1 + dp[j]);
        //     }
        // }
        ans = max(ans, dp[i]);
        max_by_element[cur] = max(max_by_element[cur], dp[i]);
        max_by_equal_element[b[i].first] = max(dp[i], max_by_equal_element[b[i].first]);
        mp[b[i].first].insert({ b[i].second,dp[i] });
    }
    // pvec(dp);
    // pvec(max_by_element);
    // pvec(max_by_equal_element);
    // for (auto& e : mp) {
    //     for (auto& p : e.second) {
    //         cout << p.first << "," << p.second << spc;
    //     }
    // }
    // ans = max number of elements in a good array formed using elements of a
    ll remove = n - ans;
    cout << remove << endl;
}



int main() {
    fastIO;
    ll t;cin >> t;fr(c, 1, t + 1) Solve(c);
    // Solve(1);
    return 0;
}

      thank you so much for your reply.

      I was able to upsolve this question because of your comment and very helpful comment in your code which explains some ideas around sorting.

      things which I was confused with

      1. why sort ( this is clear coz we want to process previous value and it is helpful to have them continuous so that we can track them in windows kind of things ) , if we don't sort then it will be difficult to club previous values together to get previous dp states faster
      2. why sort in reverse direction for index -> this is needed because when we look at previous states, in case of b[j].first == b[i].first-1 .. if we take j then we also take previous values, so if we sorted in non-decreasing order .. then we might pickup some indexes which are smaller than b[i].second as dp[j] would have used it .. but in this reverse sort.. dp[j] only consumes greater indices so all of them are valid
      3. why the editorial says suffix max for b[j].second = b[i].second-1 .. in a sense we take indices which are greater than b[j].second so it is suffix max but actually coz b is sorted in non-increasing order.. in a range of b we are actually storing prefix max .. which I figured while coding it out.

+2

For problem DD, Claim : For each value xx, in the optimal solution we only remove a prefix and a suffix from pos[x]pos[x] (where pos[x]pos[x] stores all indices having value xx.)

Proof : Removing an element xx from the array is equivalent to deleting its index from pos[x]pos[x]. Consider the smallest value xx in the array. Suppose it appears kk times and we remove rr of them in the optima solution. Note that we shall remove smallest positions ,if we remove any non-prefix elements, a smaller index of xx may occur before some occurrence of x+1x+1 , hence greedily we shall remove only the prefix of them i.e. smallest rr positions from pox[x]pox[x].

Now for x+1x+1, to keep all remaining xx after it, we must remove some largest positions (suffix) from pos[x+1]pos[x+1]. From here all the violations between xx and x+1x+1 are taken care of. Now we need to take care from x+1x+1 to remaining , and again by similar reasoning as earlier we would remove a prefix of pos[x+1]pos[x+1] and continue in the same manner. Thus, each pos[x]pos[x] loses elements only from its prefix and suffix.

    The editorial just focuses on the implementation without explaining why or what we are doing. I'll explain what the DP states are and why they're sufficient in this comment, you can probably follow the editorial or find your own implementation from there. Forget about DP states temporarily, our problem wants to maximize the number of elements that we can retain without erasing. Let's analyze a case where only values x — 1 and x exist (the generalization will follow), you'll note that if you keep the jth index with value x in your final array, then it is also optimal to keep all indices lesser than j with this value (since, to include the j_th index, we need to erase all indices with value x — 1 and index less than j, but that means we erase all the elements which could bother x with lower indices, so we add those to our final array to maximize elements)

    This yields a "brute force" DP solution, where our states are the current value x (n possibilities), and the position of the last index with this value we are including in our answer (naively also n possibilities), and we can make transitions considering the last index with value x — 1 that was taken

    This can be reduced to a linear solution by noting that you don't need to consider all possibilities for the last index taken with a certain value since the total number of such states across all value is obviously n, so you can speed this up with a two-pointer + suffix max solution like the one that the editorial describes (you can also consult my submission if that helps)

    peltorator has a very neat greedy solution in a comment above that is very insightful, highly recommend checking it out

+9

An alternative solution for Problem F.

First, you need to have solved the linear-time version of CODE FESTIVAL 2017 Final J — Tree MST (note that the official editorial is not the linear version). I will first explain that version here (Chinese solution).

solution

This problem is similar to one from The 3rd Universal Cup, Stage 33: Yet Another MST Problem:

You are given an undirected connected graph GG with nn vertices and mm edges, and a subset of vertices SS called the key vertices.

Construct a complete weighted undirected graph HH on the vertex set SS, where the weight between uu and vv is the shortest distance between those two vertices in GG.

Find the minimum spanning tree (MST) of HH.

The intended solution is to perform a multi-source BFS with all key vertices inserted into the queue. Each vertex records which key vertex it is closest to, and the corresponding distance. For every edge (u,v,w)(u,v,w), if their nearest key vertices are different (say ss and tt), we add an edge (s,t,dist(u,s)+dist(v,t)+w)(s,t,dist(u,s)+dist(v,t)+w) into a candidate edge set EE. Finally, sort EE and run Kruskal’s algorithm. The complexity is O(n(logn+α(n)))O(n(log⁡n+α(n))).

The correctness can be argued informally: for any path between two different key vertices pp and qq, there must exist an edge whose endpoints belong to different nearest key vertices. So it suffices to consider all such edges.

If you understand that problem, then:

For each vertex ii, create a virtual vertex i+ni+n and connect them with an edge of weight xixi. Use the virtual vertices as the key vertices and apply the above algorithm. You just need to replace the multi-source BFS with a multi-source Dijkstra.

Reference implementation still runs in O(n(logn+α(n)))O(n(log⁡n+α(n))).

However, since the graph is actually a tree, we can compute shortest distances with two DFS passes—one upward, one downward—achieving the same result.

Furthermore, note that there are exactly n−1n−1 edges satisfying “the two endpoints have different nearest key vertices.”

This is because if we treat the “nearest key vertex” as a color, then each vertex has one of nn colors, each color appears at least once, and the set of vertices of the same color forms a connected component.

It can be proven that there are exactly n−1n−1 edges connecting vertices of different colors (consider contracting each color component).

Since there are only n−1n−1 such edges, all of them appear in the MST. Thus, we can directly sum their contributions to the answer without running Kruskal. Note that the implementation computing “nearest key vertex” must ensure that vertices of the same color form a connected component.

In the reference implementation, key vertices are not explicitly constructed, but the idea is the same—when accumulating the final answer, add the contribution for cases where the colors of ii and i+ni+n differ.

The time complexity is O(n)O(n).

Now, inspired by this idea, consider this problem.

We enumerate all pairs of vertices (u,v)(u,v) in the tree. Since all edge weights are 11, any edge x↔yx↔y satisfying “the nearest key vertices of its two endpoints are uu and vv” must lie around the center of the path between uu and vv:

u - ? - ? - x - y - ? - ? - v

Ignoring for now the case where the path length is even, we see that for this to happen, every vertex closer to xx than uu cannot be chosen as a key vertex. Similarly for yy and vv. That’s the rough idea.

However, a issue: for a given vertex, there may be multiple vertices at the same distance from it. How do we handle that?

We can treat each vertex as a pair (dist(u,x),u)(dist(u,x),u). If two vertices have the same distance, we sort by the second element as a tie-breaker. Thus, we can always determine a total order, and the “nearest key vertex” is the one with the smallest such pair.

We can then process all pairs in the subtree rooted at xx (with parent yy), obtaining all pairs (dist(u,x),u)(dist(u,x),u), sorted via radix sort. Similarly for yy with respect to vv.

Now, for each case where dist(x,u)=dist(y,v)dist(x,u)=dist(y,v), let c0c0 be the number of pairs smaller than uu, and c1c1 be the number of pairs smaller than vv. These vertices are fixed as non-selectable. All others are free to choose, so the contribution is 2n−2−c0−c1×dist(u,v)2n−2−c0−c1×dist(u,v).

When dist(u,v)dist(u,v) is even, since we always choose the “nearest and smallest-index” key vertex, we simply shift the midpoint x↔yx↔y slightly toward the larger of u,vu,v. (When the midpoint is equidistant from both sides, the smaller of u,vu,v is chosen as the key vertex, so the edge x↔yx↔y effectively moves one step toward the larger side.)

347219078
